questions.text: The first structure to encounter at renal hilum during laparoscopic nephrectomy is?
questions.solution:
At the renal hilum,

  • The first structure encountered (i.e. the uppermost) is the renal vein
  • Then the renal artery
  • Lastly the renal pelvis.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 27th Edition, Chapter 76, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1399.

choices.text: The ipsilateral testis and vas deferens are usually absent

questions.text: Which is not true regarding renal agenesis?
questions.solution:
Renal agenesis is the complete absence of one kidney.

  • It results from failure of connection between the metanephric blastema and the ipsilateral ureteric bud.
  • This condition is an autosomal dominant trait with incomplete penetrance.
  • Typically, there is an absent ipsilateral ureter and the ipsilateral hemi-trigone is missing in the bladder.
  • The remaining kidney is usually hypertrophic but may also be dysplastic.
  • In addition, the ipsilateral testis and vas deferens are usually absent and in some patients the adrenal gland on the affected side is missing as well.
  • Females with the condition may have an absent ovary or Fallopian tube.
  • Renal agenesis is different from renal aplasia where there is a small dysplastic kidney.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1466.

questions.text: Congenital condition shown in the image is?
questions.solution:
The fetal kidney arises in the pelvis and ascends to attain its normal position. During the ascent, the renal pelvis also rotates from facing anteriorly to facing more medially.

The most common anomaly is for the renal pelvis to face anteriorly and the more ectopic the kidney, the more severe is the rotational abnormality.

In the majority of cases of renal ectopia, both kidneys are fused.

In crossed renal ectopia, both kidneys are fused and are on the same side - one of the ureters, therefore, crosses the midline to enter the bladder on the correct side of the trigone.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1466.

questions.text: Retrograde pyelography hints toward what diagnosis in the given image?
questions.solution:
The image shows a left double ureter (Duplex ureters)

  • Unilateral > > Bilateral
  • More common in girls.
  • Incomplete duplex - arise if the ureteric bud bifurcates after its initial development from the mesonephric duct.
  • Complete ureteric duplication occurs when there are 2 separate ureteric buds.
  • Asymptomatic in adults but associated with vesico-ureteric reflux in children.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1467 and 1468.

questions.text: Intravenous urography of a patient is shown below. This is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
• The image shows the classic cobra head
  • This is seen in a ureterocoele (cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter).

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1467.

choices.text: Polycystin-1 and polycystin-2 play a critical role
Visible haematuria occurs in up to 40% of patients with ADPKD
Hypertension is the least common manifestation of ADPKD

questions.solution:
Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD)-

  • Due to mutations in Polycystin-1 (chromosome 16) and polycystin-2 (chromosome 4).

Features -

  • Renal size increases with age resulting in a flank or abdominal mass in some patients.
  • Cysts contain clear fluid, thick brown material or coagulated blood.
  • Visible haematuria occurs in up to 40% of patients with ADPKD.
  • Cyst haemorrhage is a frequent complication with or without haematuria, depending on whether the cyst communicates with the collecting system or not.
  • Hypertension is the most common manifestation of ADPKD and a major contributor to renal disease progression and cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.
  • After the age of 20 years, most patients are hypertensive.
  • Associated with intracranial aneurysms in 10% of cases.

VHL disease is a rare autosomal dominant disorder that is characterised by multiple pathologies, including clear-cell RCC (ccRCC), pheochromocytoma, retinal angiomas and haemangioblastomas of the brainstem, cerebellum or spinal cord.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1482.

choices.text: If untreated, can lead to renal scarring
Classically, costovertebral angle tenderness is absent
CECT kidney is the investigation of choice

questions.text: All of the following are related to acute pyelonephritis, except?
questions.solution:
Acute pyelonephritis-

  • More common in females, especially during childhood, at puberty, after intercourse and during pregnancy.
  • Suggested by fever (temperature >38°C), rigors, flank pain, nausea and vomiting, and costovertebral angle tenderness.
  • Cystitis symptoms may or may not be present.
  • Symptoms may vary from a mild illness to a severe illness with septic shock, renal failure and a threat to life.
  • Pyuria is almost always present.
  • Both urine and blood are sent for culture.
  • Imaging of the kidney is necessary in the hospitalised patient to rule out pyonephrosis, perirenal abscess and obstruction of the collecting system by renal calculi.
  • CECT scan - Investigation of choice - Decreased opacification of the affected parenchyma, typically in patchy, wedge-shaped or linear distribution.
  • If untreated, it leads to renal scarring.

Acute pyelonephritis This commonly occurs as a result of ascending infection from organisms in the lower tract, usually caused by Gram-negative bacteria. Haematogenous spread may be seen in patients with diabetes and in immunocompromised hosts, people who inject drugs and patients with bacterial endocarditis. It is more common in females, especially during childhood, at puberty, after intercourse and during pregnancy. Acute pyelonephritis usually presents with fever, chills, flank pain, nausea and vomiting. Loin tenderness may be present. Symptoms may vary from mild to severe illness with septic shock and renal failure. Pyuria is almost always present and its absence in a patient with pyelonephritis may point towards an obstructed urinary tract. Urine and blood should be collected for culture. Escherichia coli and other Gram-negative organisms are commonly responsible. Imaging is necessary when the patient is not responding to antibiotics to rule out pyonephrosis, renal abscess and obstruction. Renal US is often the first imaging modality used. Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) typically shows decreased patchy opacification of the affected parenchyma.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1471.

choices.text: Grade IV: additional blunting of fornices
Grade III: reflux into the ureter and renal pelvis
Grade I: reflux into the ureter

questions.text: Not true regarding grading of vesico-ureteric reflux?
questions.solution:
Vesico-ureteric reflux (VUR) is graded as follows:

VUR is confirmed by a micturating cystogram and a DMSA scan is used to assess the degree of renal scarring.

Grades I-III generally resolve spontaneously.

Surgery (ureteric reimplantation, periureteric injections of Teflon or collagen) -

  • Episodes of acute pyelonephritis recur despite antibiotic therapy.
  • Severe reflux accompanied by a surgically correctable malformation.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1473.

choices.text: Gas detected on a CT scan

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding emphysematous pyelonephritis, except?
questions.solution:
Emphysematous pyelonephritis -

  • Fulminant, necrotising, life-threatening variant of acute pyelonephritis
  • Caused by gas-forming organisms - E Coli (most common), Klebsiella pneumoniae, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Proteus mirabilis.
  • Up to 90% of cases occur in diabetic patients and urinary tract obstruction may be present.
  • Symptoms are suggestive of pyelonephritis and there may be a loin mass.
  • Gas is detected on imaging (plain film, ultrasound, or a CT scan).

Treatment -

  • Intra-venous broad-spectrum antibiotics
  • Percutaneous catheter drainage with relief of obstruction
  • Nephrectomy - in severe cases

Emphysematous pyelonephritis This is an acute-onset, rapidly progressive, possibly lethal form of pyelonephritis characterised by parenchymal necrosis and gas formation, caused by organisms including E. coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Proteus mirabilis. Most patients have diabetes (up to 90%) and they may have obstruction secondary to calculi or papillary necrosis. Increased glucose levels in those with diabetes may provide a substrate for carbon dioxide production from fermentation. Symptoms are suggestive of pyelonephritis and an abdominal mass may be palpable. CECT of the abdomen is diagnostic and shows gas in the renal parenchyma, collecting system or both, along with other features of infection such as abscess, obstruction and perinephric stranding. Early diagnosis, intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics and percutaneous drainage of the abscess and obstructed kidneys have improved outcomes in these patients. Emergency nephrectomy is rarely required and is reserved for patients who do not respond to the described measures.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1471.

choices.text: Involves the distal ureters and bladder

questions.text: Which is not true regarding genitourinary tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Genitourinary tuberculosis-

  • Caused by dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is thus always secondary TB. There is either reinfection or reactivation of old TB.
  • It is a cause of sterile pyuria.
  • Spreads from the kidney to involve the distal ureters and bladder around ureteric orifices.

Treatment -

  • Short-course of anti-tubercular drugs as fewer organisms are involved compared with pulmonary TB and drugs tend to concentrate in the urine.
  • Surgery is done for excision of dead tissue (partial or total nephrectomy) and reconstructive surgery (for ureteric strictures, augmentation cystoplasty).

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1472.

choices.text: High oxalate in urine increases risk of stone formation
Prolonged immobilisation is one of the causes
Type II RTA is associated with stone formation
Non contrast CT scan is the investigation of choice

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding nephrolithiasis, except?
questions.solution:
Type I RTA is associated with stone formation due to hypercalciuria and low urinary citrate excretion.

Prolonged immobilisation and high urinary oxalate are associated with nephrolithiasis.

Non contrast CT scan is the investigation of choice.

Patients with a family history of stone disease are 2.5 times more likely to develop stone disease themselves. Examples of hereditary forms of stone disease include cystinuria, type I renal tubular acidosis (RTA) and primary hyperoxaluria.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1472.

choices.text: Generates shockwaves outside the body which are focused on the stones
Uric acid stones are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness

questions.text: Which statement is not true regarding ESWL?
questions.solution:
Cystine stones are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness.

ESWL - extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy-

  • Non-invasive method of treating urinary tract stones by generating shockwaves outside the body which are focused on the stones.
  • Renal calculi and stones up to 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment.

Complications of ESWL -

  • Infections by bacteria colonising the stones - prophylactic antibiotics given.
  • Hematuria, parenchymal haemorrhage, perirenal haematoma
  • Steinstrasse ('street of stones') - a collection of stone fragments in a ureter after ESWL.

Contraindications to ESWL-

  • Obese patients
  • Pregnant patients
  • Patients taking oral anticoagulants

Cystine stones Cystine stones constitute approximately 1% of stones. Cystinuria is an autosomal recessive inherited disease that causes decreased reabsorption of cystine from the intestine and the proximal tubule of the kidney. Cystine is insoluble even at physiological pH and worsens with increasing acidity. Cystine stones are very hard stones as a result of disulphide bonds and do not fragment with SWL.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1475.

questions.text: A 35 years old male patient post right side ESWL (for 1.3 cm right renal calculus) presents with severe right flank pain and vomiting. On X ray following image is seen. What is the probable finding?
questions.solution:
The image shows a right side steinstrasse in the distal right ureter along with right lower pole calculi.

A collection of stone fragments in a ureter after ESWL is given the German name of steinstrasse ('street of stones')

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1476.

choices.text: Obese patients in whom extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) is contraindicated
Anatomic abnormalities such as PUJ Obstruction along with the stone

questions.text: All of the following are indications for percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL), except?
questions.solution:
Indications for percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL) include -

Any obstruction -

  • Anatomic abnormalities such as PUJ obstruction, calyceal diverticula
  • Ureteric obstruction a prevents the passage of stone fragments after ESWL.

Obese patients in whom ESWL is contraindicated.

Lower calyceal stones - these are less likely to pass after ESWL.

Stone composition -

  • Struvite stones need to be completely removed because of associated infection.
  • Some stones with a very hard composition are difficult to fragment using ESWL, including calcium oxalate monohydrate and cystine stones.

Percutaneous nephrolithotomy PCNL involves removal of renal stones by creating a track between the skin and the pelvicalyceal system. Typically, this procedure is done in the prone position. Fluoroscopy or US is used for localisation. The posterolateral calyx is commonly chosen for entry. US in conjunction with pneumatic and laser lithotripsy is the most common energy source used. Complications include bleeding, infection and pleural violation in cases of supracostal puncture. Severe bleeding may require selective angioembolisation.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1477.

questions.text: A 22 years old male patient is diagnosed with PUJ obstruction for which he has been advised surgery. Following are the representative images. Which procedure has been performed?
questions.solution:
• In the original Anderson-Hynes open pyeloplasty, the upper third of the ureter and the renal pelvis are mobilised, the ureter is dismembered from the renal pelvis, redundant renal pelvis is excised and a new PUJ is reconfigured.

The Anderson-Hynes dismembered pyeloplasty is the procedure of choice with a wide funnelled, dependent anastomosis, maintaining good vascularity of the upper ureter and pelvis and excision of the redundant pelvis. The indications for pyeloplasty are persistent pain, hypertension, haematuria, secondary renal calculi and recurrent UTls. Endoscopic management in the form of endopyelotomy is reserved for post-pyeloplasty strictures.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1469.

choices.text: Expanding subcapsular haematomas compressing the kidney

questions.text: All of the following findings comprises of Grade 4 renal injury, except?
questions.solution:
Ureteropelvic avulsions are seen in grade V renal injury.

Renal injuries are classified as follows:


Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1479.

questions.text: A 67 years old gentleman with significant history of smoking diagnosed with right side renal mass, which is of 5 cm in size and renal vein thrombosis is also present. What will be the stage for the given case?
questions.solution:
CT imaging with contrast enhancement of the chest, abdomen and pelvis is required for optimal staging.

Tumour staging

The treatment and prognosis of RCC depends on its pathological staging. The most important factors are the size of the tumour and whether it is confined within the renal capsule and Gerota's fascia. Involvement of the lymph nodes, renal sinus and vein wall are associated with a poorer prognosis than the presence of tumour thrombus in the renal vein or IVC. Currently the most commonly used system for staging RCC is the TNM classification.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1483.

choices.text: Tyrosine kinase inhibitors targeting the VEGF signalling axis that are approved in the first-line therapy
Anti-VEGF monoclonal antibody, bevacizumab, is approved for use with interferon
The average duration of disease control with these drugs is 3-4 weeks in the first-line Setting

Many studies are currently investigating combinations of anti-VEGF therapy with a new generation of immunotherapy agents in the form of T cell-immune checkpoint inhibitors such as antibodies against programmed cell death protein 1 ligand 1 (PDL1)

questions.text: Which statement is not correct regarding medical management of RCC?
questions.solution:
• The past 10 years have seen the approval of several targeted therapeutic agents for the treatment of metastatic RCC.
  • Given the highly vascular nature of RCCs, it is unsurprising that several therapies are available to exploit this feature.
  • Indeed, tyrosine kinase inhibitors targeting the VEGF (vascular endothelial growth factor) signalling axis that are approved in the first-line and second-line settings for the treatment of metastatic RCC are sorafenib, sunitinib, pazopanib, axitinib, lenvatinib and cabozantinib.
  • In addition, the anti-VEGF monoclonal antibody, bevacizumab, is approved for use with interferon-α.
  • The motor inhibitors everolimus and temsirolimus, are approved as single agents in the second-line setting and in the first-line setting in patients with poor risk status.
  • The average duration of disease control with these drugs is 8-9 months in the first-line setting and 5-6 months in the second-line setting.
  • Most of the phase III RCTs leading to approval of these agents have excluded patients with nccRCC.
  • Many studies are currently investigating combinations of anti-VEGF therapy with a new generation of immunotherapy agents in the form of T cell-immune checkpoint inhibitors such as antibodies against programmed cell death protein 1 ligand 1 (PDL1), which include avelumab and atezolizumab, and antibodies against programmed cell death protein 1 (PD1) which include nivolumab and pembrolizumab.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery 28th Edition, Chapter 82, The Kidney and Ureter, Pg: 1484-1485.
